para.text: Once the web page and Silverlight client have been loaded into the browser, no further communication with the web server occurs. All communication is now between the client and the application server. The diagram below is an example of the interaction between the client and the server to give you an idea of how the Web Viewer actually works. Some steps have been removed for the sake of simplicity, but what is important to note is that all the work is done on the server, even processing the user's mouse activity when they are working with images. In the example, the user is zooming the image, and the server is sending new images back to the client.

The client and server are in constant communication via the application service, and the connection is maintained for the duration of the user's session. Simply put, the application service is a two-way messaging service that not only allows the client to talk to the server, but also allows the server to "push" updates to the client. There are two examples of this in the diagram: the "Viewer Created" and "Image Updated" events are pushed back to the client by the server. An important thing to note is that, although such events are often triggered by a message from the client, they are

simply responses to that message. A single message from the client can cause multiple updates to be pushed back from the server. For example, the spatial locator tool in the viewer is activated when the user clicks and drags in a tile, but that action can actually cause the images in all visible tiles to change/update.
